title: 104_s638
content: SECTION 1. TERRITORIAL AND FREELY ASSOCIATED STATE INFRASTRUCTURE ASSISTANCE. Section 4(b) of Public Law 94-241 is amended to limit payments to the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands for fiscal years 1996 and beyond to amounts specified in the Agreement of the Special Representatives on Future Federal Financial Assistance. The additional amounts available under this section in any fiscal year will be provided for capital infrastructure projects in various territories, including American Samoa, Guam, the Virgin Islands, the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, Palau, Micronesia, and the Marshall Islands. In fiscal year 1997, $3 million will be allocated to the College of the Northern Marianas, with up to $3 million annually for immigration, labor, and law enforcement issues in the Northern Mariana Islands. Projects will be outlined in a five-year infrastructure plan developed by the Secretary of the Interior in consultation with the island governments. The Secretary of the Interior, in consultation with island governments, develops a five-year plan for capital infrastructure needs, highlighting priority projects and considering factors like master plans, Corps of Engineers' reviews, maintenance set-asides, local cost-shares, and proposing incremental set-asides up to $2 million annually. The Secretary of the Interior may propose an incremental set-aside of up to $2 million per year as an emergency fund for natural disasters. Additional contributions for infrastructure and resettlement of Rongelap Atoll may be made, not exceeding $32 million from any Federal source after January 1, 1995. Contributions for resettlement of Rongelap Atoll after January 1, 1995 may not exceed $32 million and must be a full settlement of US obligations. Federal agencies in the Marshall Islands can provide funds for resettlement through the Secretary of the Interior. Ex gratia assistance is also available for individuals not choosing to resettle. The Compact of Free Association Act of 1985 provides assistance for individuals not resettling at Rongelap, contingent on full funding for resettlement being provided first. SEC. 2. FEDERAL MINIMUM WAGE. Effective thirty days after enactment, minimum wage provisions of the Fair Labor Standards Act will apply to the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, with rates starting at $2.75 per hour and increasing annually. The minimum wage rate in the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands will be adjusted to match the rate set forth in section 6(a)(1) of the Fair Labor Standards Act once it reaches that level. The minimum wage rate in the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands will be adjusted to match the rate set forth in section 6(a)(1) of the Fair Labor Standards Act once it reaches that level. SEC. 3. REPORT. The Secretary of the Interior, in consultation with other government officials, must report to Congress by March 15 each year on funds allocated for immigration, labor, and law enforcement activities in the CNMI. The report includes immigration data and conditions of non-U.S. workers. The Secretary of the Interior must report to Congress annually on various issues in the CNMI, including the treatment of non-U.S. workers, the impact of local laws on federal interests, detention facility adequacy, alien identification system reliability, and reasons for federal law enforcement challenges in the Commonwealth. The Secretary of the Interior must report annually to Congress on issues in the CNMI, including challenges faced by Federal agencies in enforcing laws without funding. SEC. 4. IMMIGRATION COOPERATION. The Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands and the Immigration and Naturalization Service will work together to identify and, if necessary, exclude or deport individuals posing security or law enforcement risks to the Commonwealth or the United States. SEC. 5. CLARIFICATION OF LOCAL EMPLOYMENT IN THE MARIANAS. Section 8103(i) of title 46 of the United States Code is amended to allow aliens in the CNMI to work as unlicensed seamen on fishing vessels within US waters. The United States allows aliens in the CNMI to work as unlicensed seamen on fishing vessels within US waters, with certain exceptions and amendments to the United States Code. SEC. 6. CLARIFICATION OF OWNERSHIP OF SUBMERGED LANDS IN THE COMMONWEALTH OF THE NORTHERN MARIANA ISLANDS. Public Law 93-435 (88 Stat. 1210) is amended to include the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands in various sections. References to enactment dates in the law now refer to the date of enactment of this specific section. The Secretary of the Interior must provide an annual report to Congress on the economic development, federal assistance, local finances, infrastructure, and financial management of various US territories and Pacific island nations. Additionally, a technical correction is made to Public Law 93-435 to include the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands. Section 501 of Public Law 95-134 is amended to include the Republic of Palau, the Republic of the Marshall Islands, and the Federated States of Micronesia. Passed by the Senate on July 20, 1995.
